skill.name: get-available-resources
skill.description: This skill should be used at the start of any computationally intensive scientific task to detect and report available system resources (CPU cores, GPUs, memory, disk space). It creates a JSON file with resource information and strategic recommendations that inform computational approach decisions such as whether to use parallel processing (joblib, multiprocessing), out-of-core computing (Dask, Zarr), GPU acceleration (PyTorch, JAX), or memory-efficient strategies. Use this skill before running analyses, training models, processing large datasets, or any task where resource constraints matter.

security_audit.summary: The skill only queries local system resources through psutil and system utilities. It writes a JSON file to the current working directory. No network access, credential harvesting, or persistence mechanisms detected. External commands are hardcoded subprocess calls to legitimate system tools (nvidia-smi, rocm-smi, sysctl).

content.value_statement: Large workloads fail when resources are unknown. This skill reports CPU, GPU, memory, and disk details with practical recommendations for scientific computing.
actual_capabilities: Detects CPU core counts, architecture, and frequency
Reports total and available RAM plus swap usage
Checks disk usage for the working directory
Detects NVIDIA CUDA, AMD ROCm, and Apple Silicon Metal GPUs
Generates recommendations for parallel, memory, GPU, and disk strategies
Writes a .claude_resources.json report with timestamp and system info
limitations: Requires Python 3.6+ and psutil package installed
GPU detection depends on system tools like nvidia-smi or rocm-smi
Disk metrics only cover the specified path
Resource readings are a point-in-time snapshot

output_examples.input: Check my machine resources and give me a quick plan for processing a large dataset.
output: CPU: 12 logical cores, recommended 10 workers for parallel tasks
Memory: 32 GB total, 18 GB available, moderate memory strategy
Disk: 1.2 TB total, 640 GB free, disk abundant
GPU: NVIDIA CUDA available, consider PyTorch or CuPy for acceleration

best_practices: Run the detection before starting heavy compute tasks
Re-run when system load changes significantly
Keep the JSON report with project documentation
anti_patterns: Setting worker counts higher than available CPU cores
Ignoring disk space before creating large intermediate files

faq.question: Is this compatible with macOS, Linux, and Windows?
faq.answer: Yes. It supports all three platforms with OS-specific GPU detection methods.

faq.question: What are the limits of resource detection?
faq.answer: Detection is a snapshot in time and depends on psutil and GPU tools being installed.

faq.question: How do I integrate it into my workflow?
faq.answer: Run the script at project start and read the JSON output to inform your computational choices.

faq.question: Does this skill collect or send my data?
faq.answer: No. It only reads local system statistics and writes a JSON file to your working directory.

faq.question: What if my GPU is not detected?
faq.answer: Ensure GPU driver tools like nvidia-smi or rocm-smi are installed and in your PATH.

faq.question: How does this compare to manual system checks?
faq.answer: It automates CPU, memory, disk, and GPU detection into a single command with recommendations.
